title: Solanum elaeagnifolium
text:
Solanum elaeagnifolium, the silverleaf nightshade or silver-leaved nightshade, is a common native plant to parts of the southwestern USA, and sometimes <a href="weed">weed</a> of western <a href="North%20America">North America</a> and also found in <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. Other common names include prairie berry, silverleaf nettle, white horsenettle or silver nightshade. In <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> it is known as silver-leaf bitter-apple or satansbos ("<a href="Satan">Satan</a>'s bush" in <a href="Afrikaans">Afrikaans</a>). More ambiguous names include "<a href="bull-nettle">bull-nettle</a>", "<a href="horsenettle">horsenettle</a>" and the <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> "<a href="trompillo">trompillo</a>". The plant is also endemic to the Middle East.
"Solanum elaeagnifolium" was described by <a href="Antonio%20Jos%C3%A9%20Cavanilles">A. J. Cavanilles</a>. The plant described under the same name by <a href="William%20Herbert%20%28botanist%29">W. Herbert</a> and <a href="Carl%20Ludwig%20Willdenow">C. L. Willdenow</a> based on <a href="Ernst%20Gottlieb%20von%20Steudel">E.G. von Steudel</a> is "<a href="Solanum%20aethiopicum">Solanum aethiopicum</a>".
Description and ecology.
It is a <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a> 10 cm to 1 m in height. The stems are covered with nettle-like <a href="prickle%20%28botany%29">prickle</a>s, ranging from very few on some plants to very dense on others. Leaves and stems are covered with downy hairs (<a href="trichome">trichome</a>s) that lie against and hide the surface, giving a silvery or grayish appearance.
The leaves are up to 15 cm long and 0.5 to 2.5 cm wide, with shallowly waved edges, which distinguish it from the closely related <a href="Carolina%20Horsenettle">Carolina Horsenettle</a> ("S. carolinense"), which has wider, more deeply indented leaves. The flowers, appearing from April to August, have five petals united to form a star, ranging from blue to pale lavender or occasionally white; five yellow <a href="stamen">stamen</a>s and a <a href="pistil">pistil</a> form a projecting center. The plant produces glossy yellow, orange, or red <a href="berry%20%28botany%29">berries</a> that last all winter and may turn brown as they dry.
Its range is from <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a> south to <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, and west through the Mexican-border states of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> into <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, as well as <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>, and <a href="Chile">Chile</a>. It may have originated in North America and was accidentally introduced to South America or the reverse. It can grow in poor soil with very little water. It spreads by <a href="rhizome">rhizome</a>s as well as seeds, and is common in disturbed habitats. It is considered a <a href="noxious%20weed">noxious weed</a> in 21 U.S. states and in countries such as <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, <a href="Israel">Israel</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>, and <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>. It is toxic to livestock and very hard to control, as root stocks less than 1 cm long can regenerate into plants. However, some gardeners encourage it as a <a href="xeriscape">xeriscape</a> <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental</a>.
The <a href="Pima%20people">Pima</a> Indians used the berries as a vegetable <a href="rennet">rennet</a>, and the <a href="Kiowa">Kiowa</a> used the seeds together with <a href="brain">brain</a> tissue to <a href="tanning%20%28leather%29">tan</a> <a href="leather">leather</a>.
Toxicity.
Ingestion of silverleaf nightshade has been implicated as a cause of <a href="ivermectin">ivermectin</a> toxicosis in horses given the recommended dosage of the drug. Metabolites from the plant are speculated to disrupt the <a href="blood-brain%20barrier">blood-brain barrier</a>, allowing ivermectin to enter and disrupt neurotransmitter function in the brain and spinal cord.
Synonyms.
This plant has been described under a range of names, all now invalid. These contain many <a href="homonym">homonym</a>s among them:
Several <a href="variety%20%28botany%29">varieties</a> and <a href="form%20%28botany%29">form</a>s of "S. elaeagnifolium" have been named. They are not usually considered <a href="taxonomical">taxonomical</a>ly distinct:
"S. elaeagnifolium" var. "ovalifolium" does not refer to the "<a href="Solanum%20ovalifolium">S. ovalifolium</a>" as described by Dunal and does not belong to the present species; it is actually "<a href="Solanum%20aridum">S. aridum</a>". Meanwhile, "S. crispum" var. "elaeagnifolium" is just the normal "<a href="Solanum%20crispum">S. crispum</a>" of Ruiz and Pavón Jiménez.
